channel.description:

item.title: Leading in deep water (Part 1 of 3) | Richard Wright (Speaker, Author, Endurance Athlete)
item.itunes:title: Leading in deep water (Part 1 of 3) | Richard Wright (Speaker, Author, Endurance Athlete)
item.itunes:subtitle: Lessons in how to survive and thrive uncertainty and adversity
item.description:
Imagine what it takes to run 42 km. A full marathon. Now, imagine doing so after cycling non-stop for 180 km. Now, imagine doing both after a 3.8 km swim. This is the journey every aspiring endurance triathlete must take to earn the coveted moniker of Ironman. Now, imagine doing all of that, in record time, with stage 4 brain cancer. In this episode, the first of three in a series with Richard Wright, a sought-after speaker, author, endurance athlete and three-time cancer survivor, we talk about what it takes to push the boundaries of our physical and mental capability to achieve apparently impossible feats, even when all the odds are against us. We talk about this not just in terms of Richard's story, or the decisions we must make every day to progress and achieve, but also critically in terms of the current state of the world - a world oppressed by the fear and uncertainty of a global COVID-19 pandemic.


Richard Wright's website http://www.iamrichardwright.com/

item.title: Myths, money and misinformation | Simon Dingle (Inves Capital | CEO)
item.itunes:title: Myths, money and misinformation | Simon Dingle (Inves Capital | CEO)
item.itunes:subtitle: A deep(er) dive into Bitcoin and blockchain technology
item.description:
Simon Dingle's first love was radio, and as such is a voice that will be familiar to many. He has featured as a leading technology commentator for the best part of twenty years and is recognised today as one of South Africa's - and arguably the world's - leading and more lucid experts in Bitcoin and fintech disruption. In this episode we talk about the philosophy of money, incentives, the dysfunction of the central banking system, the pros and cons of cryptocurrencies, and one or two other bonus tid bits. I count Simon one of my closest friends, someone who has been a rock and a sounding board in many key moments in my life. He spends the majority of his time now on Lettuce, a project focused on dramatically improving the world of money. Before that he was part of the teams that started 22seven, Curve, and Luno. He also wrote a book called In Math We Trust. And in case you didn't immediately gather so from the show, he is also one of the more authoritative and informative public speakers on the circuit (you should book him, immediately.)


Simon Dingle's website, and a hub for catching up on all the interesting work he's done and is doing. https://www.simondingle.com/#

Lettuce is building an open banking hub that brings the world of investments together. It’s an objective, independent hub for your money. https://lettuce.money/

item.itunes:title: A new brand of leadership | Sam Rockey (ThompsonHarrison | Co-founder
item.itunes:subtitle: Lessons and learnings from the bleeding edge of leadership development.
item.description:
Samantha Rockey is a global expert in the fields of leadership development and organisational change, and the co-founder of London-based leadership development and organisational development firm Thompson Harrison. Sam is deeply motivated be helping leaders discover what really matters in their quests to build more fulfilling personal lives and more impactful, successful organisations. A Joburger by birth and by heart, Sam is a dear friend who has played a significant role in my professional career, as my very first corporate client at Cerebra, as a mentor, and now as a colleague. I play a role as the digital capability lead in Thompson Harrison's global offering. We talk about the questions modern leaders are being forced to ask to stay relevant, the value of an appreciation for complexity and nuance, and some of the key forces driving changes in leadership dynamics the world over.


Thompson Harrison, one of London's leading bespoke leadership development consulting firms. https://thompsonharrison.com/

item.itunes:title: Data, diversity and Hunters Gold | Lerato Semenya (Chromatic | Managing Director)
item.itunes:subtitle: How effective leaders are turning heaps of data into insight and wisdom.
item.description:
In this episode I talk to data maven and transformation evangelist Lerato Semenya about a range of topics related to the challenge of leveraging big data for better decision-making in modern organisations. Lerato has just launched a new venture called Chromatic to assist corporations in facilitating tangible shifts in intention and application around diversity and inclusion initiatives, after a very successful career in data science with a major bank, energy company and talent management conglomerate.


Chromatic Consulting is focused on helping clients simplify, plan and execute their Diversity and Inclusion (D&I) journeys. https://chromatic.africa

item.title: Leading through critical thinking | Jacques Rousseau (UCT | Lecturer)
item.itunes:title: Leading through critical thinking | Jacques Rousseau (UCT | Lecturer)
item.itunes:subtitle: If there was a gym for your brain, would you pay a subscription?
item.description:
I talk to Jacques Rousseau, lecturer at the University of Cape Town, author, secular activist and social commentator on his area of expertise, critical thinking and ethics. We explore the benefits of applying rational thought to leadership, the pros and cons of social media (and specifically Twitter), the lost art of conversation and debate, and many more topics.


Jacques Rousseau's blog. https://www.synapses.co.za/

What's missing in discussions on politics, ethics, religion, and society, a podcast hosted by Jacques Rousseau and Greg Andrews. https://squarebrackets.co.za/

The EDX Science of Everyday Thinking course that Jacques recommended for executives who want to advance their critical thinking skills. https://www.edx.org/course/the-science-of-everyday-thinking
